awd_titl_txt: Solar Wind and Illumination Control of Plasma Irregularity Production in the Polar Cap
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to improve our understanding of ionospheric irregularities, building on recent work at high southern latitudes that demonstrated a clear connection between the interplanetary magnetic field (IMF) and irregularity production in the auroral E-region. The fundamental issue to be addressed is solar control of irregularity production via indirect IMF effects versus direct effects of solar-induced ionization. This study will focus on evaluating the extent of IMF control of small-scale irregularities and the relationship to other scales. The project will address the question of whether the presence of the polar patches is a necessary condition for irregularity production, and whether solar illumination suppresses or enhances irregularity generation. Inter-hemispheric differences will be investigated to determine the relative importance of solar wind drivers versus solar ionization.

Earlier studies of small-scale plasma irregularities have analyzed local observations using rockets and/or radio techniques. This project will analyze irregularity production in the polar cap in context of its global drivers focusing on observations from the first US Antarctic HF (SuperDARN) radar at McMurdo, Antarctica and complementary instrumentation. The polar cap ionosphere is directly connected to the solar wind; hence, one can expect IMF effects on small-scale irregularity production to be even more pronounced than in the previously studied auroral region. The polar cap also has reasonably uniform solar ionization conditions near solstices and sharp contrasts between seasons, so solar illumination effects can be revealed more clearly. In addition, the polar cap appears to be especially rich in irregularities. 

This project will leverage data from the NSF-funded Antarctic facilities, providing essential support for a newly-established faculty researcher in the US, and expand a graduate student training program in the geosciences area in Alaska.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of the work supported by this award derives from analysis of radar returns from the polar F region, particularly using radars within the Super Dual Auroral Radar Network (SuperDARN) in the polar cap in both hemispheres and the northern face of the Resolute Bay incoherent scatter radar (RISR-N). The conducted research broadly falls within two groups of studies: (1) experimental investigation of plasma density structures in the ionospheric F region and their global solar control and (2) improvement of theoretical understanding of SuperDARN radar backscatter formation in the polar cap regions. Plasma structures in the polar cap range in size from thousands of kilometers to centimeter scales and the work under this award also focused on the relationship between different scales.

Within the first group of studies, an experimental statistical investigation using the SuperDARN Rankin Inlet and McMurdo radars showed that solar effects in plasma density irregularity production at small scales occur both through solar illumination control of plasma density and through solar wind control of convection environment [Lamarche and Makarevich, 2015]. Analysis of the RISR-N observations revealed that large-scale plasma density structures propagating from the dayside can be a significant refilling source for deep depressions in the plasma density in the wintertime polar cap [Lamarche and Makarevich, 2015; Makarevich et al, 2015]. In addition, it was shown that deep depressions in the plasma density in the polar cap do not necessarily require very slow or very fast convection in contrast to model predictions [Makarevich et al., 2015]. In the most recent experimental study, a novel analysis technique of coordinated radar observations by RISR-N and the SuperDARN Rankin Inlet radar has been developed [Lamarche and Makarevich, 2017].  Analysis showed a general consistency of plasma irregularity occurrence trends with those expected from the linear fluid theory of the gradient-drift instability (GDI), but the relationship with echo power was found to be far less straightforward [Lamarche and Makarevich, 2017].

Within the theoretical group of studies, a general fluid theory of GDI has been developed that resulted in a unified view of GDI across the entire lower ionosphere including the ionospheric F region [Makarevich, 2014]. A modeling study of asymmetries in plasma irregularity characteristics near gradient reversals based on this theory was undertaken that revealed a critical role of propagation direction in controlling asymmetry magnitude [Lamarche and Makarevich, 2016]. This has important implications for radar observations near gradient reversals which are often observed within the polar cap plasma (e.g. polar patches and sun-aligned arcs). The GDI theory has been later expanded to include other fundamental ionospheric plasma instabilities in the broad range of altitudes [Makarevich, 2016a]. Analytic analysis of the general dispersion relation demonstrated strong inertial effects on decameter waves in the F region seen by SuperDARN [Makarevich, 2016b]. Finally, using the developed general dispersion relation, it was estimated that in the F-region, from which most of the SuperDARN backscatter comes, primary small-scale waves can be generated for plasma density gradient scales as large as 100 km for favorable orientations and strong plasma convection and that much smaller scales are required for unfavorable orientations [Makarevich, 2017].

Broader Impacts: This award has supported one PhD student at the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) and has provided her dissertation topic. The outcomes of this award have also been used in classroom teaching at UAF.

 

References:

1. Lamarche, L. J., and R. A. Makarevich, Solar control of F region radar backscatter: Further insights from observations in the southern polar cap, J. Geophys. Res. Space Physics, 120, 9875-9890, doi:10.1002/2015JA021663, 2015.

2. Lamarche, L. J., and R. A. Makarevich, A modeling study of asymmetries in plasma irregularity characteristics near gradient reversals, Ann. Geophys, 34, 709-723, doi:10.5194/angeo-34-709-2016, 2016.

3. Lamarche, L. J., and R. A. Makarevich, Radar observations of density gradients, electric fields, and plasma irregularities near polar patches in the context of the gradient-drift instability, J. Geophys. Res. Space Physics, 122, 3721-3736, doi:10.1002/2016JA023702, 2017.

4. Makarevich, R. A., Symmetry considerations in the two-fluid theory of the gradient drift instability in the lower ionosphere, J. Geophys. Res. Space Physics, 119, 7902-7913, doi:10.1002/2014JA020292, 2014.

5. Makarevich, R. A., Toward an integrated view of ionospheric plasma instabilities: Altitudinal transitions and strong gradient case, J. Geophys. Res. Space Physics, 121, doi:10.1002/2016JA022515, 2016a.

6. Makarevich, R. A., Toward an integrated view of ionospheric plasma instabilities: 2. Three inertial modes of cubic dispersion relation, J. Geophys. Res. Space Physics, 121, doi:10.1002/2016JA022864,  2016b.

7. Makarevich, R. A., Critical density gradients for small-scale plasma irregularity generation in the E- and F-regions, J. Geophys. Res. Space Physics, 122, doi:10.1002/2017JA024393, 2017.

8. Makarevich, R. A., L. J. Lamarche, and M. J. Nicolls, Resolute Bay incoherent scatter radar observations of plasma structures in the vicinity of polar holes, J. Geophys. Res. Space Physics, 120, 7970-7986, doi:10.1002/2015JA021443, 2015.
